Hartree-Fock-Bogoliubov Decomposition


We can write the Hamiltonian in the way that makes the Hermiticity manifest, taking into account duplicates properly





\begin{align}
H &= \sum_{ij} T_{ij} c_{i}^{*} c_{j}
 + \frac{1}{4} \sum_{ijkl} c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{l} c_{k}
\\
  &= \sum_{i} T_{ii} c_{i}^{*} c_{i}
    + \sum_{i \lt j} (T_{ij} c_{i}^{*} c_{j} + T_{ij}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{i}) \\
  &\quad
  + \frac{1}{4} \sum_{i < j}
  \left[
      V_{ijij} c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{j} c_{i}
    - V_{ijij} c_{j}^{*} c_{i}^{*} c_{j} c_{i}
    - V_{ijij} c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{i} c_{j}
    + V_{ijij} c_{j}^{*} c_{i}^{*} c_{i} c_{j}
  \right]
  \\
  &\quad
  + \frac{1}{4} \sum_{\substack{(i<j), (k<l) \\ \text{ and } \\ (i,j) < (k,l) }}
  \left[
      V_{ijkl}     c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{l} c_{k}
    - V_{ijkl}     c_{j}^{*} c_{i}^{*} c_{l} c_{k}
    - V_{ijkl}     c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{k} c_{l}
    + V_{ijkl}     c_{j}^{*} c_{i}^{*} c_{k} c_{l} \right.\\
  &\qquad \left.
    + V_{ijkl}^{*} c_{k}^{*} c_{l}^{*} c_{j} c_{i}
    - V_{ijkl}^{*} c_{l}^{*} c_{k}^{*} c_{j} c_{i}
    - V_{ijkl}^{*} c_{k}^{*} c_{l}^{*} c_{i} c_{j}
    + V_{ijkl}^{*} c_{l}^{*} c_{k}^{*} c_{i} c_{j}
  \right]
\\
&= \sum_{i} T_{ii} c_{i}^{*} c_{i}
  + \sum_{i \lt j} (T_{ij} c_{i}^{*} c_{j} + T_{ij}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{i}) \\
&\quad
  + \sum_{i < j}
  \left[
      V_{ijij} c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{j} c_{i}
  \right]
  + \sum_{\substack{(i<j), (k<l) \\ \text{ and } \\ (i,j) < (k,l) }}
  \left[
      V_{ijkl}     c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{l} c_{k}
    + V_{ijkl}^{*} c_{k}^{*} c_{l}^{*} c_{j} c_{i}
  \right]
\end{align}








\begin{align}
  \Gamma_{ij} &= \sum_{kl} V_{ikjl} \rho_{lk} \\
  \Gamma_{ik} &= \sum_{jl} V_{ijkl} \rho_{lj} \\
  \Delta_{ij} &= \frac{1}{2} \sum_{kl} V_{ijkl} t_{kl}
\end{align}







Diagonal Interaction


Let us first consider the 
diagonal
 interaction of the form





  V c_{1}^{*} c_{2}^{*} c_{2} c_{1} ,





which is the Hermitian conjugate of itself. Following [Goodman][Goodman80], this interaction decomposes into the following mean fields in the particle-hole and particle-particle channels:








Interaction


PH Channel


PP Channel










V(1212) =  V


Γ(11) =  V ρ(22)


Δ(12) =  ½ V t(12)






V(1221) = -V


Γ(12) = -V ρ(12)


Δ(12) = -½ V t(21)






V(2112) = -V


Γ(21) = -V ρ(21)


Δ(21) = -½ V t(12)






V(2121) =  V


Γ(22) =  V ρ(11)


Δ(21) =  ½ V t(21)








Here, the equal sign '=' does not indicate equality. Rather, it refers to the contribution of the right hand side to the mean field on the left hand side. Some of the mean fields are redundant, as required by the Hermiticity of the Hamiltonian. Overall, we end up with





\begin{align}
\Gamma_{11} &=  V \rho_{22} \\
\Gamma_{12} &= -V \rho_{12} \\
\Gamma_{22} &=  V \rho_{11}
\end{align}





in the particle-hole channel, and





\begin{align}
\Delta_{12} =  V t_{12}
\end{align}





in the particle-particle channel.




Offdiagonal Interaction


Now let us consider the 
offdiagonal
 interaction term of the form





  V c_{1}^{*} c_{2}^{*} c_{4} c_{3}.





Given this term in the interaction, it is implied that its Hermitian conjugate





  V^{*} c_{3}^{*} c_{4}^{*} c_{2} c_{1}.





is also included in the Hamiltonian. The two terms (the explicit term and its Hermitian conjugate) decomposes into








Interaction


PH Channel


PP-Channel










V(1234) =  V


Γ(13) =  V ρ(42)


Δ(12) =  ½ V t(34)






V(1243) = -V


Γ(14) = -V ρ(32)


Δ(12) = -½ V t(43)






V(2134) = -V


Γ(23) = -V ρ(41)


Δ(21) = -½ V t(34)






V(2143) =  V


Γ(24) =  V ρ(31)


Δ(21) =  ½ V t(43)
















V(3412) =  V*


Γ(31) =  V ρ(24)


Δ(34) =  ½ V t(12)






V(3421) = -V*


Γ(32) = -V ρ(14)


Δ(34) = -½ V t(21)






V(4312) = -V*


Γ(41) = -V ρ(23)


Δ(43) = -½ V t(12)






V(4321) =  V*


Γ(42) =  V ρ(13)


Δ(43) =  ½ V t(21)








As we have mentioned above for the diagonal interaction terms, this table contains redundant mean fields. Overwall. we have





\begin{align}
\Gamma_{13} &=  V  \rho_{24}^* \\
\Gamma_{14} &= -V  \rho_{23}^* \\
\Gamma_{23} &= -V  \rho_{14}^* \\
\Gamma_{24} &=  V  \rho_{13}^*
\end{align}





in the particle-hole channel and





\begin{align}
\Delta_{12} &=  V   t_{34} \\
\Delta_{34} &=  V^* t_{12}
\end{align}





in the particle-particle channel.

Hamiltonian: Full Interacting Hamiltonian




Terms of Hamiltonian


HartreeFockBogoliubov.jl
 currently supports Hamiltonian with hopping and (quartic) interaction terms. The hopping terms can be grouped into "diagonal" terms and "offdiagonal" terms:





\begin{align}
H_{\text{diagonal-hopping}} &= \sum_{i} t_{ii} c_{i}^{*} c_{i} \\
H_{\text{offdiagonal-hopping}} &= \sum_{i \neq j} t_{ij} c_{i}^{*} c_{j}
\end{align}





The hermiticity of the Hamiltonian requires that $t_{ii}$ be real, and $t_{ij} = t_{ji}^{*}$. Thus we can rewrite the offdiagonal term as





H_{\text{offdiagonal-hopping}} = \sum_{i \lt j} t_{ij} c_{i}^{*} c_{j} + t_{ij}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{i}





To incorporate this we define two 
struct
s: 
HoppingDiagonal
 and 
HoppingOffdiagonal
:

{
R
:
Real
}

    
amplitude
 
::

i
 
::

Ri
 
::

{

}


end

{

Ri

 and 
j
 are integers representing the "index" of the orbital, and 
Ri
 and 
Rj
 represents which unitcell they are in. The "unitcell coordinates" 
Ri
 and 
Rj

HoppingOffdiagonal

which represent





U c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{j} c_{i}, \qquad i \lt j





and





U     c_{i}^{*} c_{j}^{*} c_{l} c_{k} +
U^{*} c_{k}^{*} c_{l}^{*} c_{j} c_{i}, \qquad
i \lt j \wedge k \lt l \wedge [ i \lt k \vee ( i = k \wedge j \lt l )]





In other words, (i,j) and (k,l) each need to be in lexicographical order, as well as $(i,j) 
 (k,l)$.

,
